annotation.TEXT: Please don't hate this chart! I know they're mostly Nvidia GPUs. AMD's seemed to have much higher tflops for the same performance so I stuck with Nvidia which seem more consistent and don't keep jumping from single to double precision. I guess that this is why the 7850 looks almost identical to the 660 in gflops but performs far less- if anything the PS4's output should be nearer the 7870.

This probably comes across wrong. I mean to say that I believe a lot that optimisation will make the consoles punch above their hardware in terms of performance. It's hard to optimise a game for different hardware specs, I guess they always aim for the best performance for the console spec and then rely on PCs and their more powerful setups to power the games with the additional bells and whistles that they add to them at the moment. At worst, the next gen of consoles will bring the baseline performance level up to that of today's PCs.

And by this I mean almost identical to highest settings. They'll probably use a cheaper AA setting and will optimise bits of the game for the console in particular. Hey, it should be able to run it well on high, the current generation can run it at lowest settings!

I know that the 8 GB of RAM is shared between the GPU and general use with the PS4, but don't care enough to mention it. I don't feel that any game at the moment even pushes 6 GB of system RAM and 2 GB of GPU RAM any way, so making comparisons or slating it for being shared would be pointless.

I stand by what I say here- I speculated this in one of my earlier videos as well and am interested to see if it comes true. Could be what AMD needs to remain competitive and will give their current processors a new lease of life.

Maybe it sounds like I'm trying to show off, but I'm trying to put across that my PC is pretty decent by today's standards and will probably be comparable to the next gen of consoles when they're released and once optimisation for their tech spec is considered. The PS4 isn't exactly weak.

Nvidia's realtime water simulation in GDC 2010. It's so PRETTY and back then they said that this is what we could expect to see in next gen games. I'm not so sure as it would suck up most of the performance the PS4 could offer (at least in this demonstration), but I'm sure a happy compromise of scale and detail could be reached.

By this I mean that the processor is a custom-made thing with more cores than an average PC would have at that time, and the graphics card, if it was for PCs, is about the same price as with the PS3/Xbox360. I talk later about how the GPUs in PCs have changed and now there's a super high-range market with crossfire / sli graphics and things such as the 690 and Geforce titan. True, there was a 7950 GX2 back when the previous gen was released but who used that? Plus SLI wasn't as good back then. 'Nuff said.

Interesting to know that the CPU and GPU in the PS4 are part of the same thing. They say that the GPU element will be less powerful when released for PCs. PS4 performance in a combined CPU/GPU (APU) is quite a feat. Well done AMD! I expect it to be less wattage than current processors because it's for a console that's designed to be in a living room, and not some power-hungry number crunching server somewhere. Anandtech, in their article on it, says the same thing. Apparently it's based on the Jaguar CPU design. Haven't researched it.

*than all the games on the previous list. Crysis 3 on highest everything seems to make it perform at around 30 fps which is on par with what games could look like on the next gen. No doubt they'll end up releasing some impressive looking games towards the later part of the console's life that will make even Crysis 3 look dated. Maybe.
In gaming ones it tends to rely on the performance of fewer cores. It's sad to see AMD's older processors still offering the same performance as more recent ones in gaming benchmarks.

Interestingly the GPUs I've had in my computers have gone: ATI Radeon, Geforce 4200 TI, Radeon 9700, Geforce 8800, Radeon 4850, Geforce 670. So I wouldn't say I'm too biased or fan-boyish. The reasons for the small jumps between the large jumps in performance in the cards I've owned would be because either another PC was needed in the house and I thought it would be nice to upgrade, or I bought one to keep up at University so I wouldn't need to keep lugging it back and forth every term. As for the chart, maybe I should have compared the 7870 to the 660, but you can easily do that for yourself if you want. I guess the chart shows that tflops aren't everything- and not in AMD's favour at the moment.

I don't know why but I've always associated the CPU as dealing with AI in games, since most RTSes seem CPU-limited. Or maybe everybody who designs those sorts of games just sucks at writing them. I mena, come on guys, if not AI then what is the CPU dealing with when playing, say, Crysis 3?

I think it's reasonable enough because the PS4 was released a year later than the Xbox360 and for a higher price for the same specification. I don't think they'll aim for the 'premium' approach again since most games were designed for both platforms, making more power somewhat useless.

Oh come on you all know that it's true. They're competitive within their price-bands, at least in terms of performance if not efficiency, but AMD tends to go down the brute-force method of adding more cores than it does by trying to improve the performance per core like Intel does. I wish that Intel would add more cores to their processors as well, but their 'low number of cores but high performance per core' seems to work well with today's applications and games. This console may change all that.
4 cores + hyperthreading, which I still think is cheating and not the same as a true 8 core CPU. Despite all that, AMD's true 8 core CPU doesn't seem to perform that much better.
